content:
Your tests and validators don't actually have any alphanumeric non-palindromes. (All non palindromes in tests have no digits, all tests with digits are palindromes)

This means that users never actually have to show that they distinguished between "alphabets" or "alphanumeric characters".

I got beaten on shortest mode by someone who just ignored the distinction between alphanumeric and alphabet and they got 100% on tests and validators.
EDITED: to avoid binary output, different outputs are demanded.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: les tests sont concluants et le puzzle est rapide à resoudre

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puts a little twist on an otherwise very simple problem. This is definitely on the easier side, but fun to solve.

Each validator must differ from the corresponding test (your first 3 validators are identical to the tests).

Each validator should check the same case as the corresponding test (Test 4 / Validator 4 do not check the same case).

"Input: A sentence" is misleading; "984651354864351848153468453156489" is not a sentence.

To avoid giving an advantage, in Shortest mode, to languages which use True/False, you should choose something other than True / False for your outputs.

You should include test case with both numbers and letters in the output.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hullo, I added a test case because in my first try I passed all tests and failed a validator (Which is the worst case scenario), turns out I had misread alphanumeric for alphabetical lol, in any case I couldn't find any identical contributions and the fact that it shouldn't consider spaces or the like makes it a little more interesting. All in all, nice contribution!

Hi Majeck, thanks for your comment and approval.
I merged tests 4 and 5 because I didn't want to duplicate. But I made the test simpler than the validator.
If it's ok for you, you can even upvote the contribution :) that will help me to have visibility.

Hi SPDene, thanks a lot for your complete and constructive comment!
I did the following changes:
- changed output to YES NO, good point
- updated tests and validators (each test has a specificity and each validator is testing the same thing as test).
- renamed input to string instead of sentence
Are you ok with this new version?
I'm not sure to get what you said, can you please give more details ?

your clash was a binary output clash. Refer to guidelines for more details on what a binary output clash is, but basically it is a clash where there are only 2 possible outputs. Someone can get half the credit if they output randomly or one of the values.

I added a test case containing both numbers and letters ("Si is 22" / "abc 12 cba" )
This is designed to fail if the solution only checks letters.
